dt.t: Cemeteries were seldom placed on the north side of a church, which, if used for burial at all, was reserved for unbaptized children, criminals, {wi}reprobates{/wi} and suicides.

shortdef: an unprincipled or depraved person : scoundrel, rogue

dt: {bc}of, relating to, or characteristic of a reprobate
{bc}rejected as worthless or not standing a test {bc}{sx|condemned||}

shortdef: of, relating to, or characteristic of a reprobate

dt: {bc}to condemn strongly as unworthy, unacceptable, or evil

pt: {sc}criticize{/sc} {sc}reprehend{/sc} {sc}censure{/sc} {sc}reprobate{/sc} {sc}condemn{/sc} {sc}denounce{/sc} mean to find fault with openly. {sc}criticize{/sc} implies finding fault especially with methods or policies or intentions.
{sc}reprehend{/sc} implies both criticism and severe rebuking.
{sc}censure{/sc} carries a strong suggestion of authority and of reprimanding.

pt.t: a Senator formally {it}censured{/it} by his peers

pt: {sc}reprobate{/sc} implies strong disapproval or firm refusal to sanction.
{sc}condemn{/sc} usually suggests an unqualified and final unfavorable judgment.
{sc}denounce{/sc} adds to {sc}condemn{/sc} the implication of a public declaration.

et: Middle English, from Late Latin {it}reprobatus{/it}, past participle of {it}reprobare{/it} {ma}{mat|reprove|}{/ma}
shortdef: to condemn strongly as unworthy, unacceptable, or evil
